Infectious Disease

Question 8

A 62-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a 4-day history of chills, crampy abdominal pain, and diarrhea that started at the end of her trip to Guatemala. She is passing five watery stools per day, although she notes this does not interfere with her daily activities. Medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medications.

On physical examination, temperature is 37.4 °C (99.3 °F), blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg, pulse rate is 92/min, and respiration rate is normal. The abdomen is soft and nontender.

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

A Azithromycin 10%
B Ciprofloxacin 5%
C Fluid replacement 82%
D Tinidazole 3%

Answer & Critique

Correct Answer: C

Educational Objective:

Treat a patient with mild travelers' diarrhea.

Key Points

  • Travelers' diarrhea is typically self-limited in immunocompetent patients (resolving within 5-7 days), and mild infections require no treatment other than supportive care.
  • Up to 80% of travelers' diarrhea infections are caused by pathogenic intestinal bacteria, including various strains of Escherichia coli (enterotoxigenic E. coli is the most common), Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, and Vibrio species.

Fluid replacement is the most appropriate treatment for this patient. Travelers' diarrhea affects one third of travelers to developing nations with poor food and water safety practices, such as sub-Saharan Africa, the Middle East, Central and South America, and Southern Asia.
